pulls.title: Add ABNF syntax description and adjust terminology
pulls.author: cyrill-k
pulls.body:
- Describe the security Property Value using ABNF syntax description, analogous to the syntax description of the issue Property Value in CAA RFC 8659

- Slight rewrite/restructuring of abstract
- Switch to one-sentence-per-line format to simplify working with git
- Adjust terminology to more closely follow CAA RFC 8659

pulls.title: Fix syntax and add SVCB Discussion
pulls.author: cyrill-k
pulls.body:
- Replace recursive syntax with syntax similar to RFC9539
- Change CA-specific option prefix from "-<ca_name>-" to "ca-<ca_name>-" to conform to new syntax
- Add proposal on how to defeat active adversaries using SVCB DNS records (address the issues raised in Appendix B of RFC9539

comments.body:
In other parts of the draft we have gone with SHOULD recommendations for this type of stuff. I am somewhat in favor of a SHOULD here. Even though having a key hash in the SVCB record is really important, my understanding is that we are no where saying we MUST use an SVCB record. Thus, this becomes a MUST within a SHOULD (i.e., if there exists and SVCB record, then it MUST have a key hash). I worry this will create non-intuitive failure behavior and require implementing parties to put in an additional check that is not part of standard SVCB record processing.

In short, I would prefer:
the SVCB records SHOULD specify parameters to validate the authenticity of the TLS...

Doesn't this need a syntax descriptor as well for what the attribute value should look like specifically? Even the phrase non-empty comma separated list could be ambiguous regarding things like leading/trailing white space etc...

I see your point that this may confusion.
I'm okay with changing it to SHOULD.

My thought process was:

1. secure policy lookup requires DNSSEC [SHOULD] OR authenticated tunnel [SHOULD if no DNSSEC]
   - "Authenticity can either be ensured by signing the security CAA record or by retrieving the security CAA record via an authenticated channel."
2. example of authenticated tunnel: DoX tunnel (RFC9593) + defense against active attacker [MUST]
   - "... MUST also implement defenses against active adversaries"
3. example of defense against active attacker: downgrade protection using DNSSEC-protected SVCB record + key authenticity using public key hash in SVCB [MUST]
   - "... MUST specify parameters to validate the authenticity of the TLS certificate ..."

The reason I used MUST is that I wanted to have a consistent terminology with the active adversary defense text, and that we need public key hashes in SVCB to fully defend against an active adversary, which may launch BGP hijacks against CAs to get fake TLS certs for the nameserver.
Alternatively, we could also require nameserver domains to protect themselves against network adversaries using DNSSEC-signed security CAA tags.
Sure, I can add syntax descriptors in this section as well :+1:
